case_title: Mst. FARIDA KAUSAR vs MUHAMMAD ASHFAQ

accussed_details.name: Muhammad Ashfaq
allegation: Recovery of golden ornaments worth Rs. 1,00,000

complaint_summary: Mst. Farida Kausar filed a suit claiming maintenance after estrangement and divorce from Muhammad Ashfaq. The respondent filed a suit for recovery of golden ornaments worth Rs. 1,00,000.
investigation_summary: The respondent did not join the proceedings despite being served through multiple processes, including registered cover A/D, telegraphic communication, and ordinary process.
judgment_summary: The court allowed the transfer application, moving the respondent's suit from Pasrur District Sialkot to Lahore for adjudication alongside the petitioner's maintenance suit.
Decision_or_verdict: Application allowed; respondent's suit transferred to Lahore.
legal_arguments: Petitioner urged transfer for feminine convenience and to avoid contradictory judgments.
Respondent's non-participation in proceedings led to ex parte decision.

legal_terms.Ex parte: Legal proceedings carried out without the presence of one party.

words_and_phrases.Feminine convenience: Consideration for the comfort and accessibility of the female petitioner.

summary_vector_notes: The case involves estrangement and divorce between Mst. Farida Kausar and Muhammad Ashfaq. The petitioner sought maintenance, while the respondent filed a suit for recovery of golden ornaments. The court allowed the transfer of the respondent's suit to Lahore for adjudication alongside the petitioner's suit, citing convenience and avoidance of contradictory judgments.

maintenance_suit.title: Mst. Farida Kausar v. Muhammad Ishfaq

golden_ornaments_suit.title: Muhammad Ashfaque v. Mst. Farida and another
golden_ornaments_suit.court: Judge Family Court, Pasrur District Sialkot

petition_details.reason_for_transfer: Feminine convenience and to avoid contradictory judgments

judgment.order: The respondent's suit is transferred from Pasrur District Sialkot to Lahore for adjudication by the court already handling the petitioner's suit.
